questions.text: A 40-year-old patient had undergone prolonged surgery in a  prone position with his hip extended. Post-operatively he complained of pain, numbness, and paresthesia along the anterolateral aspect of the thigh. What is the root value of the nerve involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with a history of prolonged surgery in prone position with hip extended and symptoms of paresthesia over the anterolateral aspect of the thigh is suggestive of meralgia paresthetica. It is due to compression neuropathy or neuroma of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve of the thigh. The root value of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is L2 and L3.

The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh arises from the posterior divisions of the ventral rami of L2 and L3, and it supplies the skin of the anterior and lateral surfaces of the thigh up to the knee.

It is prone to injury especially as it leaves the pelvis deep to the inguinal ligament just medial to the anterior superior iliac spine. The angulation of the nerve as it crosses the iliac crest makes it vulnerable to compression during hip extension which may increase angulation and tension on the nerve.

Related Pearl: Compression neuropathies

Syndrome 

Nerve involved

Pronator teres syndrome

Median nerve (proximally compressed beneath ligament of Struthers, bicipital aponeurosis, or origins of pronator teres)

Radial tunnel (Arcade of Frohse) syndrome

Posterior Interosseous nerve (in proximal forearm)

Cubital tunnel syndrome

Ulnar nerve behind medial epicondyle

Cheiralgia Paresthetica (Wartenburg syndrome)

Superficial sensory branch of radial nerve

Carpal tunnel syndrome

Median nerve (at wrist)

Guyon's canal syndrome

Ulnar nerve(at wrist)

Thoracic outlet syndrome

Lower trunk of brachial plexus

Tarsal tunnel syndrome

Posterior tibial nerve

Piriformis syndrome

Sciatic nerve
Meralgia paresthetica Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh
Mortons Metatarsalgia Interdigital plantar nerve 
Notalgia Paresthetica Superficial sensory neuropathy in the infrascapular area (Pruritus + Dysaesthesia)

questions.text: The MR angiography of a patient is shown below. Which of the following structures is predominantly supplied by the artery marked in the image?
questions.solution:
The artery marked in the image of MR angiography is the anterior cerebral artery. It predominantly supplies the corpus callosum.

Circle of Willis is a large arterial anastomosis that unites the internal carotid and vertebrobasilar systems. It lies in the subarachnoid space within the basal cisterns surrounding the optic chiasma and infundibulum.  

The images below show the MR angiography and the cadaveric image of the Circle of Willis, respectively. 

The anterior cerebral artery is a terminal branch of the internal carotid artery. 

The anterior cerebral arteries course along the great longitudinal fissure, passing around the curve of the genu of the corpus callosum along its upper surface and ends to anastomose with posterior cerebral arteries. It gives the following branches.

Cortical branches  Areas supplied

1. Orbital branches 

  
  • Olfactory cortex
  • Gyrus rectus
  • Medial orbital gyrus
2. Frontal branches
  • Corpus callosum
  • Cingulate gyrus
  • Medial frontal gyrus
  • Paracentral lobule
  • Fornix
 3. Parietal branches
  •  Precuneus
Central branches
  • Rostrum of the corpus callosum
  • Septum pellucidum
  • Anterior part of the putamen, Head of the caudate nucleus and adjacent parts of the internal capsule
 

The cortical branches of the anterior cerebral artery supply the motor and somatosensory areas of the cerebral cortex that represent the lower limb.

Other options:

Option A: The thalamus is supplied by posterior communicating arteries, posterior cerebral arteries, and the basilar artery. 

Option B: The medulla oblongata is supplied by the vertebral artery, anterior and posterior spinal arteries, posterior inferior cerebellar arteries, and basilar artery. 

Option C: The midbrain is supplied by posterior cerebral arteries, superior cerebellar arteries, and the basilar artery. 

Related Pearl: Circle of Willis

Related Pearl: Blood supply of Brain

The brain is supplied by Internal Carotid arteries and Vertebrobasilar arteries. 

Areas supplied by various arteries
Anterior Cerebral Artery

Course - Curves around the corpus callosum within the sagittal fissure

Supply - Dorsomedial frontal and parietal lobes

Effects of occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery (ACA): 

- Contralateral Paralysis (or weakness) of muscles of the leg and foot - Upper part of motor area affected.

- Contralateral Loss (or dulling) of sensations from the leg and foot - Upper part of the sensory area affected.
Middle Cerebral Artery

Course - Runs within Sylvian fissure

Supply - Lateral convexity of the cerebral cortex

Effects of occlusion of middle cerebral artery (MCA):

- Contralateral Hemiplegia -  loss of sensations. The face and arms are most affected, foot and leg are spared.  

- Aphasia - Broca’s and Wernicke’s areas affected, especially if the thrombosis is in the left hemisphere in a right-handed person.  

- Contralateral Homonymous hemianopia - due to the involvement of optic radiation.  
Posterior Cerebral Artery

Course - Curves behind the midbrain

Supply - Occipital lobe and inferior and medial temporal lobe

Effects of occlusion of posterior cerebral artery (PCA):

- Contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing - Affected Cortical blood supply > Damage to association cortex of visual area causes visual hallucinations (distortion of colour vision).

Note: Macular sparing is due to collateral circulation from MCA to that cortical region. 

Related Pearl: Arteries supplying specific parts of the brain

Parts of Brain Arteries supplying it
Basal ganglia
  • Lateral striate artery - a branch of MCA
  • Medial striate artery - a branch of ACA
  • Anterior and posterior  choroidal arteries
  • Thalamogeniculate branch of PCA
Internal capsule
  • Lateral striate artery - a branch of MCA
  • Medial striate artery (Recurrent artery of Heubner) - a branch of ACA
  • Anterior choroidal artery - a branch of ICA
Thalamus
  • Posterior communicating arteries
  • Posterior cerebral arteries
  • Basilar artery
Midbrain
  • Posterior cerebral arteries
  • Superior cerebellar arteries
  • Basilar artery
Pons
  • Basilar artery
  • Anterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • Superior cerebellar arteries.
Medulla oblongata
  • Vertebral artery
  • Anterior and posterior spinal arteries
  • Posterior inferior cerebellar arteries
  • Basilar artery
Cerebellum
  • Superior cerebellar arteries
  • Anterior inferior cerebellar arteries
  • Posterior inferior cerebellar arteries

 

ACA - Anterior cerebral artery

MCA- Middle cerebral artery

PCA - Posterior cerebral artery

ICA - Internal carotid artery

questions.text: A 17-year-old male patient is suggested to undergo surgery for shoulder dislocation. Which of the following nerve block is recommended?
questions.solution:
Interscalene block is recommended for the surgical procedures involving the shoulder.

In interscalene block, the blockade occurs at the level of the superior and middle trunks of brachial plexus. It is performed by injecting a local anesthetic to the nerves of the brachial plexus as it passes through the groove between the anterior and middle scalene muscles, at the level of the cricoid cartilage.

Advantages of this block include rapid blockade of the shoulder region, and relatively easily palpable anatomical landmarks.

Disadvantages of this block include inadequate anesthesia in the distribution of the ulnar nerve, which makes this an unreliable block for operations involving the forearm and hand.

Image below depicts an interscalene block.

Other options:

Option A: Indications for a supraclavicular block are operations on the elbow, forearm, and hand. Blockade occurs at the distal trunk-proximal division level.

Image below depicts a supraclavicular block.

Option B: Infraclavicular block provides anesthesia to the arm and hand. Blockade occurs at the level of the cords.

Image below shows an infraclavicular block.

Option D: Indications for axillary block include surgery to the forearm and hand. Elbow procedures are also performed. Blockade occurs at the level of the terminal nerves. Although blockade of the musculocutaneous nerve is not always produced with this approach, it can be supplemented at the level of the axilla or at the elbow.

Image below depicts an axillary block.

Related Pearl: Brachial Plexus Blocks

 

Name of Block Level of Block Adequate Analgesia Seen at Limitations
Interscalene Superior and middle trunk Shoulder and upper arm. Most intense effect at C5-C7 dermatomes. Ulnar nerve (C8,T1) sparing
Supraclavicular Distal trunk and proximal division Elbow, forearm and hand Axillary and suprascapular nerve sparing; Pneumothorax, phrenic nerve palsy
Infraclavicular Cords Elbow, forearm and hand Intercostobrachial nerve sparing
Axillary Terminal nerves

Forearm and hand.

  • Most intense block in C7-T1 (Ulnar nerve) distribution
  • Least intense in C5-C6 dermatome
  • Most optimal for procedures from elbow to hand

 

 Musculocutaneous, axillary, medial cutaneous nerve branches sparing; Inadvertent intravascular injection

questions.text: A young man presents to the physician with a history of erosions on the scalp, face, and chest for the past 6 months. He says that initially, the lesions were like fluid-filled blisters, which later ruptured to form erosions. On examination, multiple lesions are seen over the scalp, face, chest, and also oral cavity. Nikolsky's sign is positive. This disease is caused due to a defect in which of the following layers?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of flaccid blisters over the skin and mucosa in a young man, along with a positive Nikolsy sign, are suggestive of pemphigus vulgaris. It mainly affects the epidermis, which is marked as 1 in the above slide.

Pemphigus vulgaris is caused by the autoantibodies that are directed mainly against desmoglein 3. This is present in the epidermis. Other intraepidermal immunobullous disorders are pemphigus foliaceous, endemic pemphigus, and paraneoplastic pemphigus.

Examples of subepidermal immunobullous disorders are bullous pemphigoid, linear IgA disease, pemphigoid gestationis, epidermolysis bullosa acquisita, etc.

Structure of skin:

The epidermis is the outermost layer of skin and is made up of five layers, or strata, of different cell types. It is made of stratified squamous keratinised epithelium and consists of the following layers. 

  • Stratum basale - It is the deepest layer of the epidermis and is made of a single layer of columnar cells. It contains keratinocytes and is also called stratum germinativum. 
  • Stratum spinosum - Contains several layers of polygonal keratinocytes. These cells are connected with the help of desmosomes. This is also called the prickle cell layer.
  • Stratum granulosum - These are made up of flattened cells that have deeply staining granules in their cytoplasm. The granules contain keratohyalin.
  • Stratum lucidum - It lies superficial to the stratum granulosum. The cell boundaries are indistinct, and this layer appears homogenous.
  • Stratum corneum - It is the most superficial layer of the epidermis. This layer is acellular. It is made up of flattened scale-like elements (squames) containing keratin filaments within a protein. The squames are held together by a glue-like material that contains lipids and carbohydrates.

The dermis is divided into two layers:

  • The papillary dermis is the superficial layer of the dermis and contains dense connective tissue of dermal papillae. The papillae are best developed in the thick skin of the palms and soles. Each papilla contains a capillary loop.
  • The reticular layer is the deeper layer of the dermis and consists of thick bundles of collagen fibres. It also has some elastic fibres. 

The dermis rests on subcutaneous tissue. The subcutaneous layer is called panniculus adiposus. It is responsible for giving a smooth contour to the skin. It is absent in the superficial fascia of the eyelids, the scrotum and the penis. 

The below image shows lesions of pemphigus vulgaris.

Related Pearl: Classification of Vesiculobullous Disorders

According to Pathology

  • Immunobullous disorders/ Primary blistering disease: occur due to autoimmunity

Intraepidermal

Subepidermal

Pemphigus vulgaris

Bullous pemphigoid

Pemphigus foliaceous

 Dermatitis herpetiformis

Pemphigus vegetans

 Epidermolysis bullous acquisita
 Pemphigus erythematosus  
  • Mechanobullous disorders: Due to defect in the structure of epidermis
    • Epidermolysis bullosa
    • Bullous ichthyosiform erythroderma
  • Other disorders
    • Infections - VZV, HSV, Bullous impetigo, SSSS
    • Metabolic - Porphyria, Diabetes, Hemodialysis
    • Drug eruptions - Fixed drug eruption, Steven Johnson Syndrome, Erythema Multiforme

According to Site

Intraepidermal

Sub-epidermal (Dermo-epidermal)

1. Subcorneal (granular layer)

  • Pemphigus foliaceous & erythematosus
  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome
  • Miliaria crystalina
  • Bullous impetigo
  • Friction blister
  • Subcorneal pustular dermatosis

2. Spinous layer

  • Eczematous (atopic) dermatitis
  • HSV/VZV infection
  • Molluscum contagiosum
  • Familial benign pemphigus (Hailey-hailey disease)

3. Suprabasal

  • Pemphigus vulgaris
  • Darrier’s disease

4. Basal layer

  • Erythema multiforme
  • Epidermolysis bullosa simplex

1. Junctional (at basal lamina)

  • Junctional epidermolysis bullosa
  • Bullous pemphigoid
  • Toxic epidermal necrolysis

2. Dermolytic (below basal lamina)

  • Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita
  • Epidermolysis bullosa dystrophicans
  • Deep burns
  • Porphyria cutanea tarda

Related Pearl: Cells of the epidermis

Cells of the epidermis Origin and location Characteristic features
Keratino-cytes

Present in- All Layers of Epidermis (90-95% of all epidermal cells)

Derived from-Ectoderm

Differentiated in situ

 Rich in the intermediate filaments called keratin that provides mechanical strength to the cell. The keratinocytes in basal layer divide and generate the upper layers. 
Melano-cytes

Present in- Stratum basale

Derived from-Neural Crest

Migrate to the epidermis

 Synthesize melanin in granules called melanosomes that is transferred to keratinocytes of epidermis through elongated processes called dendrites. Each melanocyte transfers melanosomes to 36 keratinocytes. This is called as Epidermal melanin unit (36K:1M)   

Merkel   cells

Present in-Stratum basale (RETE RIDGES)

Derived from-Ectoderm/ Neural Crest

Differentiates in-situ

 Also known as Touch cells or Haascheiban cells. They are Type 1 slow adapting touch receptors.  
Langerhans cells

Present in-Stratum spinosum

Derived from- Bone Marrow

Migrate to Epidermis

 They are dendritic Antigen Presenting Cells (APCs).   Characterized by presence of rod shaped or Tennis Racket shaped granules called Birbeck granules which are seen on electron microscopy.   Immunohistochemical Markers are CD1a, CD207(Langerin) and S100.

questions.text: A 75-year-old cachexic man presents with nagging back pain in the lumbar region that shoots down his right leg. He was diagnosed with prostate cancer 2 months back. Which of the following movements is anatomically restricted in the lumbar region?
questions.solution:
Rotation is anatomically restricted in the lumbar region.

The given clinical vignette is suggestive of carcinoma prostate, which has metastasised to the lumbar spine. Anatomically, the lumbar region of the vertebral column has a restricted range for rotational movements.

Movements of the vertebral column:

  • Flexion of the spine is accompanied by relaxation of the anterior longitudinal ligament and compression of the anterior parts of the intervertebral discs. Flexion is effectively absent in the thoracic region. Flexion movements are greater than extension or lateral flexion in the lumbar region.
  • Extension is marked in cervical and lumbar regions. It is significantly less at thoracic levels as their discs are thinner and because of the ribs and chest musculature.
  • Lateral flexion is flexion combined with coupled axial rotation. Lateral movements occur in all parts of the column but are the greatest in the cervical and lumbar regions.
  • Axial rotation is the highest in the cervical region, 50% of which occurs at the atlantoaxial joint. All the other spine segments below the cervical have only a slight range of rotation, among which the thoracolumbar junction has the most. The remainder of the lumbar region has very little rotation.

questions.text: During a thyroidectomy, the surgeon accidentally damages the nerve marked in the image below. Which of the following is true about the postoperative course in this patient?

choices.text: Initial hoarseness in voice which may improve with time

questions.solution:
The structure marked in the above image is the left recurrent laryngeal nerve. Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis will lead to initial hoarseness of voice, which may improve with time.

Recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis can be unilateral or bilateral. Unilateral palsy is more common on the left side because of the long course of the nerve. They are more commonly injured during thyroid surgeries, neck trauma, thyroid disease, and bronchogenic carcinoma.

The recurrent laryngeal nerve supplies all the muscles of the larynx except for the cricothyroid. Therefore, in unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy, these muscles are paralysed. The affected vocal cord lies in the paramedian position (option B).

Postoperatively, the injury can go unnoticed, or the patient may complain of mild hoarseness in the voice. This hoarseness is because the paralysed muscle cannot close the glottis during phonation.

Hoarseness might improve over time because the unaffected muscle compensates and closes the glottis by hyperadduction of the cord. The patient will not have difficulty in breathing or stridor (option C).

Generally, no treatment is required (option A). Laryngoplasty type I is needed if there is no compensation from the normal muscle.

In bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy, both the vocal cords are paralysed and assume the paramedian position. Because the vocal cords are close to the midline, the phonation can be normal. However, since these vocal cords cannot abduct, the patients will have stridor and breathing difficulty. This condition requires an emergency tracheostomy to maintain the patient's airway.

The image given below shows the nerves of the neck.

Related Pearl: Various Vocal Cord Palsies

Type of palsy U/L Abductor B/L Abductor U/L complete B/L complete
Nerve RLN (left) Both RLNs RLN+SLN (left) Both RLN+SLN
Cord position Paramedian   |\ Both in  Paramedian   || Cadaveric   [\ cadaveric (intermediate) position [[
Voice Hoarse Good Hoarse Aphonia
Dyspnea - + - -
Aspiration - - +/- +
Treatment Wait & watch (palsy with least consequences) Tracheostomy, lateralization Wait & watch, medialization Tracheostomy + Epiglottopexy

Guide: \ is normal moving cord; | is paramedian; [ is cadaveric.

Related Pearl: Nerves of Larynx

Related Pearl: Positions of the Vocal Cord

Position Distance from median Seen in
Median 0 During speech/ swallowing
Paramedian 1 mm Recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy
Intermediate/ Cadaveric 3 mm Complete paralysis
Slight abduction 7 mm Normal respiration
Full abduction 9 mm Strained respiration

questions.text: A patient is suspected to have had an iatrogenic injury to the pharyngeal plexus during surgery. All of the soft palate muscles would be affected by the injury except?
questions.solution:
Except for Tensor veli palatini, all the other muscles can be affected in the given scenario. All the soft palate muscles are supplied by the pharyngeal plexus, except tensor veli palatini, which is supplied by the nerve to the medial pterygoid, a branch of the mandibular nerve.

All soft palate muscles are derived from the 4th pharyngeal arch and are supplied by the vagal plexus/pharyngeal plexus, except tensor veli palatini, which is derived from the 1st pharyngeal arch and supplied by the mandibular nerve.

The pharyngeal plexus is formed by the pharyngeal branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve and the vagus nerve with contributions from the superior cervical sympathetic ganglion. It supplies:

  • All muscles of the soft palate, except tensor veli palatini which is supplied by the mandibular nerve
  • All the muscles of the pharynx, except the stylopharyngeus which is supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve.

Note:

  • All tongue muscles are supplied by the hypoglossal nerve except the palatoglossus (supplied by the vagus nerve through the pharyngeal plexus).
  • All the muscles of the pharynx are supplied by the pharyngeal plexus, except the stylopharyngeus (supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve) 
  • All larynx muscles are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, except the cricothyroid (supplied by the external laryngeal nerve).

Related Pearl: Derivatives of Branchial Apparatus

questions.text: A young man who had fractured his left humerus previously now does not feel pain in his left little finger. On examination, the following deformity is observed. Which of the nerves is most likely to have been involved?
questions.solution:
The deformity shown is cubitus valgus. This, along with the patient’s history of previous humerus fracture followed by loss of sensation over the little finger, points to the involvement of the ulnar nerve.

Cubitus valgus can occur as a late complication of nonunion of fracture of the lateral condyle of the humerus. The cubitus valgus deformity leads to the stretching of the ulnar nerve, resulting in classic neuropathic symptoms, which is termed tardy ulnar nerve palsy. Paresthesia in the ulnar nerve distribution with atrophy of the intrinsic hand muscles can be seen. It can be treated with ulnar nerve transposition and cubitus valgus correction.

The ulnar nerve supplies the medial two lumbricals in the hand. The lumbricals have a combined action on metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint flexion and interphalangeal (IP) joint extension (glass holding posture). In ulnar nerve injury, since the medial lumbricals are not functional, the forearm muscles are unopposed. Hence, there is hyperextension at MCP joints and flexion at IP joints. This causes claw hand deformity. There is also numbness in the medial one-and-a-half fingers. 

Related Pearl: Dermatome of upper limb

Related Pearl: Fractures/dislocations and associated nerve injuries

Fracture/Dislocation Nerve injured
Fracture clavicle Brachial plexus
Anterior or inferior shoulder dislocation Axillary (circumflex humeral) nerve
Proximal humerus fracture Axillary nerve
Shaft of humerus fracture Radial nerve
Supracondylar fracture humerus  Anterior interosseous nerve > Median nerve > Radial nerve
Medial condyle of humerus  Ulnar nerve
Posterior dislocation elbow Ulnar nerve >Median nerve
Monteggia fracture Posterior interosseous nerve
Volkman’s ischemic contracture Anterior interosseous nerve
Hook of hamate fracture Deep branch of the ulnar nerve
Lunate dislocation  Median nerve
Wrist injury Median nerve
Posterior hip dislocation Sciatic nerve
Anterior dislocation of hip and shaft femur fracture Femoral nerve
Knee dislocation Common peroneal nerve
Proximal tibial fractures and ankle injury Posterior tibial nerve
Fracture neck of the fibula Lateral popliteal nerve (common peroneal nerve)

Related Pearl: Upper limb nerve integrity tests

questions.text: A 23-year-old female patient with a previous history of cesarean section presented with 8 weeks of delayed periods, vaginal spotting, and sharp abdominal pain. The urine pregnancy test is positive. A transvaginal ultrasound revealed an empty uterine cavity. Based on the findings, identify the most common location of implantation for the underlying condition.
questions.solution:
The underlying condition based on the given clinical scenario of a young female with delayed periods, vaginal spotting, and sharp abdominal pain with positive UPT and empty uterine cavity on TVS is suggestive of ectopic pregnancy. The most common location of implantation in ectopic pregnancy is the tubal ampulla. 

Almost 95% of ectopic pregnancies implant within the fallopian tube. Within the fallopian tube, the ampulla is the most commonly affected location in 70% of the cases. The remaining implant is in the isthmus (12%), fimbria (11%), and interstitial tube (2%). 

The other sites of implantations are the ovary (Option A), peritoneal cavity, cervix (Option B), or prior cesarean scar (Option C). 

The classic triad of symptoms for an ectopic pregnancy is delayed menstrual cycle, abdominal pain, and vaginal bleeding. 

The examination may reveal abdominal tenderness, pain in cervical motion, a bulging posterior vaginal fornix, boggy mass next to the uterus. Vaginal bleeding or spotting may be present. Ruptured ectopic will lead to intraabdominal haemorrhage, leading to reciprocal changes in vital signs. 

Investigations used to diagnose ectopic pregnancy include a positive beta-human chorionic gonadotropin to diagnose a pregnancy. Transvaginal ultrasound can be used to identify the gestational sac or determine if the case is a pregnancy of an unknown location. In an ectopic pregnancy, the endometrial stripe will appear as a trilaminar pattern and anechoic fluid collections may be present. 

Medical management of ectopic pregnancy involves the use of methotrexate, a folic acid antagonist. Surgical management depends on whether the patient is hemodynamically stable (laparoscopy versus laparotomy) and whether she desires future fertility (salpingectomy versus salpingostomy).

Related Pearl: Fallopian tube

Gross anatomy:

The fallopian tube is divided into the following parts:

  • Intramural/Interstitial portion:  
    • Intrauterine
    • The narrowest and shortest part
  • Isthmus:
    • The most common site for tubectomy
  • Ampulla:
    • The longest and widest part
    • The most common site for - fertilization and ectopic pregnancy
  • Infundibulum

Histology:

The ampulla, isthmus and infundibulum are extrauterine. They're covered by three layers: 

  • Mesosalpinx - It is the peritoneal layer. Also called serosa.
  • Myosalpinx - It contains smooth muscle and has 2 layers:
    • Inner circular 
    • Outer longitudinal
  • Endosalpinx - It is the mucosal layer. It has the following features:
    • Numerous branching folds, filling the entire lumen
    • Basement membrane
    • Ciliated, columnar epithelium 
    • Peg cells - non-ciliated epithelium. They help in the capacitation of sperms. 

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: Which of the following marked structures is blocked as labour analgesia during 2nd stage of labour?
questions.solution:
The pudendal nerve block is used for labour analgesia during 2nd stage of labour, and the pudendal nerve corresponds to the marked structure '2' in the image above.

The pudendal nerve crosses the greater sciatic foramen to rest on the ischial spine (where the block is given), then crosses the lesser sciatic foramen to enter the perineum. 

Other structures in the above image are as follows:

1 - Superior gluteal nerve and vessels
3 - Posterior cutaneous nerve of thigh 
4 - Sciatic nerve 

Related Pearl: Structures Passing Through the Sciatic Foramens

Structures passing through the greater sciatic foramen

The piriformis is the key muscle of this region. It emerges from the pelvis, and fills the foramen almost completely.

Structures passing above the piriformis

  • Superior gluteal nerve
  • Superior gluteal vessels

Structures passing below the piriformis

  • Inferior gluteal nerve         
  • Inferior gluteal vessels
  • Sciatic nerve                                              
  • Posterior cutaneous nerve of thigh
  • Nerve to quadratus femoris                  
  • Pudendal nerve
  • Internal pudendal vessels                                  
  • Nerve to obturator internus

Note: The last three structures, after a short course in the gluteal region, enter the lesser sciatic foramen, where the pudendal nerve and internal pudendal vessels run in the pudendal canal.

Structures passing through the lesser sciatic foramen

  • Tendon of obturator internus
  • Pudendal nerve
  • Internal pudendal vessels
  • Nerve to obturator internus

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient presents with complaints of right flank pain for the past 2 months. His blood counts, urinalysis and renal function tests were normal. Abdominal ultrasound showed right hydronephrosis. A retrograde ureteropyelogram showed a right-sided fish-hook ureter with hydronephrosis. Which of the following embryological abnormality is responsible for his condition?

choices.text: Incomplete fusion of the urethral folds
Failure of  fusion of the paramesonephric duct
Two ureteric buds arising from mesonephric duct
Persistence of the posterior cardinal vein

questions.solution:
The clinical features and a right-sided fish hook ureter are suggestive of the retrocaval ureter, and it is due to the persistence of the posterior cardinal vein.

The circumcaval ureter, or retrocaval ureter, is a developmental anomaly of the inferior vena cava (IVC). This congenital abnormality occurs due to the persistence of the posterior cardinal vein, and the ureter passes posterior to the inferior vena cava. The anomaly always appears on the right side, as this is the side of the normal IVC.

This condition occurs in 1 in 1500 individuals. Most commonly, it does not produce any clinical manifestations, but rarely, it can cause upper ureteric obstruction. Even though it is a congenital anomaly, the clinical manifestations are not seen until 3rd and 4th decades of life. The clinical manifestations are a result of right-sided hydronephrosis, which can be due to kinking of the ureter, an adynamic ureteric segment, or compression of the ureter against the psoas muscle.

The classical appearance of the retrocaval ureter is termed a fish-hook ureter. As the right ureter hooks behind the IVC, it has also been referred to as an S-shaped ureter.

Other options:

Option A: Incomplete fusion of the urethral folds leads to hypospadias, a condition in which abnormal openings of the urethra occur along the ventral aspect of the penis.

Option B: Failure of fusion of the paramesonephric duct produces duplication of the uterus(e.g., Uterus didelphys, bicornuate uterus, etc.)

Option C: Two ureteric buds arising from the mesonephric duct lead to duplex ureters.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked "A" in the CT scan of the thorax shown below.
questions.solution:
The structure marked "A" in the CT Thorax is the ascending aorta.

In a CT study, X-rays are applied in a circular motion and body tissue slices are recreated mathematically. Different tissues are seen with different intensities, depending on the proportion of attenuation of the X-rays that pass through them.

  • Air and water are displayed as low-intensity (dark appearance) areas because they produce only little attenuation.
  • Bone is displayed as a high-intensity structure (bright appearance) because of its significant attenuation.
  • High density is seen in the presence of hyperemia, freshly clotted blood, and contrast agents.
  • Edema and necrosis are seen as low-intensity areas.

questions.text: A male patient was diagnosed with a submandibular gland tumour and posted for surgical removal of the gland along with its duct. Following surgery, he developed a loss of general sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. However, the taste sensations are present. Which of the following nerves is likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
General sensation from the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue is carried by the lingual nerve, which is likely to be injured in this case.

In the anterior two-thirds of the tongue,

  • General sensation is carried by the lingual nerve.
  • Taste sensation is carried by the chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve.

In the posterior one-third of the tongue, both general and taste sensations are carried by the glossopharyngeal nerve.

Valleculae are supplied by the internal laryngeal branch of the vagus nerve.

Related Pearl: Sensory Innervation of Tongue

Area

General sensory

Special sensory

Anterior 2/3rds

Lingual nerve (CN V)

Chorda tympani (CN VII)

Posterior 1/3rd

Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)

Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)

Posterior most tongue (vallecullae, epiglottis)

Internal laryngeal nerve (CN X)

Internal laryngeal nerve (CN X)

questions.text: A gynecologist is examining a 28-year-old female patient. On performing a per vaginal examination, the lowest part of the cervix that can be palpated is the anterior lip. What information does that convey about the position of the uterus and cervix?

choices.text: External os is directed forwards and downwards
Uterus is flexed backwards on cervix
External os is directed backwards and downwards
Uterus is directed backwards and downwards

questions.solution:
If the examining fingers palpate the anterior lip as the lowest part of the cervix, it means that the uterus is anteverted and the external os is directed downwards and backwards.

The normal position of the uterus is antiflexed and anteverted, ie the body of the uterus is flexed forwards on the cervix and the external os is directed downwards and backwards.

In a retroverted uterus, the external os of the cervix is directed downwards and forwards. The lowest part of the cervix palpated is the posterior lip. The body of the uterus may also be flexed backwards in a retroverted uterus.

The angle of anteversion: The angle between the cervix and vagina. Normally it is 90 degrees. (Remember: V for version, V for vagina)

The angle of anteflexion: The angle between cervix and uterus. The angle is at the level of the internal os and is 120 degrees.

questions.text: During a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the surgeon is attempting to identify the Calot’s triangle. All of the following structures identified by the surgeon are the boundaries of the Calot's triangle except?
questions.solution:
The inferior surface of the liver marked as 4 does not form the boundary of Calot’s triangle. It forms the superior boundary of the hepatobiliary triangle.

The boundaries of Calot’s triangle are 3C's

  • Medially – Common hepatic duct
  • Inferiorly – Cystic duct
  • Superior – Cystic artery

Clinical importance: Identification of Calot’s triangle is important during laparoscopic cholecystectomy for safe ligation and division of cystic duct and cystic artery.

Related Pearl: Calot's triangle and hepatobiliary triangle

Boundaries Calot's Triangle Hepatobiliary Triangle

Superiorly

 Superior border of the cystic artery Inferior surface of the liver

Medially

 Common hepatic duct

Inferiorly

 Cystic duct

Contents of Calot’s triangle:

  • Lymph node of Lund - Sentinel lymph node for the gallbladder
  • Branching of cystic artery from the right hepatic artery

questions.text: While assisting in an abdomino-perineal resection, the surgery resident injures the anorectal ring. Which muscle is not likely to be injured in this case?
questions.solution:
The muscular ring at the anorectal junction is called the anorectal ring. The anorectal ring is not formed by the rectal longitudinal muscle, but rather by the fusion of the puborectalis, deep fibres of the external anal sphincter, and the internal anal sphincter. 

The rectal longitudinal muscle fuses with the puborectalis to form a conjoint longitudinal coat that goes between the external and internal sphincter and, at the level of the white line, becomes a fibroblastic septum which pierces the external sphincter and is attached to the peri-anal skin as the corrugator cutis ani.

The anorectal ring may be felt posterolaterally during a digital per-rectal examination but is deficient anteriorly where the puborectalis is not present. Injury or division of the anorectal ring may lead to faecal incontinence.

The puborectalis is shaped like a sling around the anorectal angle, hooked to the pubis, and has a role in continence by keeping the anorectal angle acute. During defecation, the puborectalis is relaxed, and the anorectal angle becomes more obtuse, favouring the passage of faeces from the rectum to the anus.

questions.text: A young boy who was driving a motorcycle at a high speed collided with a tree and was thrown on his right shoulder.  An X-ray of the patient is given below. Which of the following nerves is affected in this patient?

choices.text: Lower lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm
Medial cutaneous nerve of the arm
Upper lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm
Posterior cutaneous nerve of the arm

questions.solution:
The X-ray indicates that this is a case of anterior shoulder dislocation, and the structure most commonly injured here is the axillary nerve. The upper lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm is a branch of the axillary nerve. 

It supplies the skin over the lower half of the deltoid.

The course of Axillary nerve:

  • Origin - Posterior cord of brachial plexus in the axilla. In the lower part of the axilla, it runs behind the third part of the axillary artery, where it lies on the subscapularis and is medial to the median nerve
  • In Axilla - Exits the axilla through the quadrangular space to enter the arm accompanied by the posterior circumflex humeral vessels.

Axillary nerve divides as anterior and posterior branches at the deltoid and supplies the following structures

  • Anterior branch - deltoid and skin over anteroinferior part
  • Posterior branch - teres minor and posterior part of the deltoid; continues as the upper lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm

Axillary nerve injury: 

It is mostly due to a fracture of the surgical neck of the humerus, inferior dislocation of the humerus, and inadvertent IM injection.

Anterior dislocation

It is the most common shoulder dislocation. It is caused by trauma from behind the shoulder pushing the head out anteriorly. It may also be caused due to falling on an outstretched hand in an abducted and externally rotated shoulder. Associated findings include tearing of the capsule, producing avulsion of the glenoid labrum (the Bankart lesion) or a crushed posterolateral part of the head, giving rise to a Hill–Sachs lesion.

The patients present with extreme pain and wish to avoid being examined. On examination, the lateral outline of the shoulder may be flattened out, and there is an inability to touch his/her opposite shoulder (Duga's test). X-ray confirms the diagnosis and shows overlapping shadows of the humeral head and glenoid fossa in AP view and a humeral head out of line with the socket in a lateral view.

Other options: 

Option A: The lower lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm is a branch of the radial nerve. Supplies the skin of the lateral side of the arm 

Option B: The medial cutaneous nerve of the arm is a branch of the medial cord.  Supplies the skin on the medial side of the inferior half of the arm, posterior to the basilic vein. 

Option D:  The posterior cutaneous nerve of the arm is a branch of the radial nerve.  Supplies the skin of the back of the arm from the insertion of the deltoid to the olecranon. 

Related Pearl: Fractures/dislocations and associated nerve injuries

Fracture/Dislocation Nerve injured
Fracture clavicle Brachial plexus
Anterior or inferior shoulder dislocation Axillary (circumflex humeral) nerve
Proximal humerus fracture Axillary nerve
Shaft of humerus fracture Radial nerve
Supracondylar fracture humerus  Anterior interosseous nerve > Median nerve > Radial nerve
Medial condyle of humerus  Ulnar nerve
Posterior dislocation elbow Ulnar nerve >Median nerve
Monteggia fracture Posterior interosseous nerve
Volkman’s ischemic contracture Anterior interosseous nerve
Hook of hamate fracture Deep branch of the ulnar nerve
Lunate dislocation  Median nerve
Wrist injury Median nerve
Posterior hip dislocation Sciatic nerve
Anterior dislocation of hip and shaft femur fracture Femoral nerve
Knee dislocation Common peroneal nerve
Proximal tibial fractures and ankle injury Posterior tibial nerve
Fracture neck of the fibula Lateral popliteal nerve (common peroneal nerve)

questions.text: A 30-year-old presents to the casualty with a history of blunt trauma to the head. MRI shows injury to the cranial nerve present in the dorsal aspect of the brainstem. Which of the following eye movements will be compromised in this patient?
questions.solution:
The trochlear nerve is the only nerve that exits the brainstem on the dorsal surface and thus can be injured in this patient. It supplies the superior oblique muscle whose actions are intorsion(medial rotation), depression, and abduction. Therefore intorsion will be compromised in this patient.

Trochlear nerve:

  • Thinnest/smallest cranial nerve
  • Only cranial nerve with dorsal exit. All other cranial nerves exit the brainstem from the ventral surface.
  • Emerges from the midbrain and passes onto the crus of the cerebral peduncle on its lateral surface.
  • Longest intracranial course.
  • Only nerve with internal decussation.

All the extraocular muscles are innervated by the oculomotor (III) nerve except, the lateral rectus which is supplied by abducens (VI) nerve and the superior oblique which is supplied by trochlear (IV) nerve.

In 4th nerve palsy, the superior oblique is affected, causing:

  • Weakness of depression: Mainly seen when the eye is adducted (depression during abducted position is a function of the Inferior rectus)
  • Weakness of abduction.
  • Failure of intorsion- Patient presents with contralateral face turn and head tilt with chin slightly depressed to avoid diplopia.
  • Normal abduction and elevation.

Related Pearl: Extraocular Muscles and Their Actions

questions.text: A patient with a splenic artery aneurysm is undergoing embolisation of the splenic artery. Following this procedure, blood flow will be reduced in all the following vessels except?
questions.solution:
Embolisation of the splenic artery would not lead to reduced blood flow in the superior pancreaticoduodenal arteries as superior pancreaticoduodenal arteries arise from the gastroduodenal artery. 

There are two superior pancreaticoduodenal arteries:

  • The anterior superior pancreaticoduodenal artery descends in the anterior groove between the second part of the duodenum and the head of the pancreas. It supplies branches to the first and second parts of the duodenum and the head of the pancreas and then anastomoses with the anterior inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery.
  • The posterior superior pancreaticoduodenal artery runs posterior to the head of the pancreas and anastomoses with the posterior inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery. It supplies branches to the head of the pancreas, the first and second parts of the duodenum, and several branches to the distal part of the common bile duct.

The splenic artery branches into the left gastroepiploic artery and the short gastric arteries near its terminus. The left gastroepiploic artery supplies the stomach, and the greater omentum, and it anastomoses with the right gastroepiploic artery.

The splenic artery runs a tortuous course along the upper border of the pancreas, and it gives off several branches to supply the pancreas. These branches include the greater pancreatic artery (Option C), dorsal pancreatic artery (Option A) and artery to the tail of the pancreas.

The arterial supply of the stomach is contributed exclusively by the branches of the celiac trunk. They are:

  1. Left gastric artery - Supplies the lesser curvature of the stomach
  2. Splenic artery- This further divides into:
     - Short gastric arteries- Supplies the fundus of the stomach
     - Left gastroepiploic artery- Supplies the greater curvature of the stomach and anastomoses with the right gastroepiploic artery
  3. Common hepatic artery, which gives the following branches.
    - Right gastric artery: Supplies the lesser curvature of the stomach, anastomoses with the left gastric artery
    - Gastroduodenal artery which further divides into:  Right gastroepiploic artery (supplies the greater curvature of the stomach) and Superior pancreaticoduodenal artery (supplies the duodenum and head of pancreas and anastomoses with the inferior pancreaticoduodenal branch of the SMA).

The following images show the blood supply of the stomach.

questions.text: A patient with breast cancer underwent the dissection of lymph nodes which are shown in the image below. Lymphatic drainage of which body part will not be affected?
questions.solution:
The infra umbilical anterolateral body wall does not drain into the axillary lymph nodes. All the remaining options listed drain into them.

Axillary lymph nodes collectively drain the entire upper limb, breast, and trunk above the umbilicus.

Axillary nodes can be divided into 5 groups:

  • Lateral/humeral
  • Anterior/pectoral
  • Posterior/subscapular
  • Central
  • Apical

Given below is a diagrammatic representation and details about the individual axillary groups of lymph nodes.

  Location Afferents Efferents
Humeral/ Lateral Group Posteromedial to the axillary vein Whole limb except vessels accompanying cephalic veins • Central nodes
• Apical nodes 
• Inferior deep cervical nodes 
Pectoral/ Anterior group Along lateral thoracic vessels Skin and muscles of supra-umbilical anterolateral body wall and breast • Central nodes
• Apical nodes
Subscapular/ Posterior group Along the subscapular vessels Skin and muscles of the inferior posterior region of the neck, dorsal aspect of the trunk up to the iliac crest • Central nodes
• Apical nodes
Central Group Embedded in the axillary pad of fat All preceding groups • Apical group
Apical group Deep to clavipectoral fascia, along the axillary vessels Those accompanying cephalic vein Unite as the subclavian trunk; the right subclavian trunk drains into the jugular-subclavian venous junction, and the left subclavian trunk ends in the thoracic duct
